title: A Six-month, Double-blind, Placebo-controlled, Single Site Study of Cerefolin NAC on Blood Homocysteine, Oxidative Stress, and Beta-amyloid Biomarkers That May Potentiate Inflammation and Neuronal Damage in Older Individuals With Memory Complaints Who Have Not Been Clinically Diagnosed With Mild Cognitive Impairment, Vascular Dementia, or Alzheimer's Disease
description_brief: The purpose of this six-month research study is to determine if Cerefolin NAC reduces levels of substances in the blood that may be associated with thinking ability and the health of brain cells in subjects with memory concerns when compared to a standard multivitamin. Cerefolin NAC is available as a dietary supplement via a prescription from a physician. The multivitamin used in the study contains the Recommended Daily Intake recommended for older persons.
description_detailed:
Study Phase: Exploratory

Indication: Memory Complaints

Study Design:

A single-center, double-blind, placebo-controlled study with 100 subjects with memory complaints followed for 6 months (4 visits)using Cerefolin® NAC or placebo once a day in addition to a standardized multivitamin.

Sample Size:

100 subjects as follows:

1. 50 on Cerefolin® NAC + multivitamin; and,
2. 50 on Placebo + multivitamin.

Primary Objective:

To determine if Cerefolin® NAC (compared to multivitamin) decreases the blood level of homocysteine, increases the blood level of glutathione (a marker for oxidative stress), and increases the ratio of Aβ42 to Aβ40 (a marker for beta-amyloid) that may be related to neuronal injury and inflammation.

Secondary Objectives:

1. To determine if Cerefolin® NAC reduces hs-CRP and TNF-α blood levels, and increases IL-6 blood levels.
2. To determine if Cerefolin® NAC (compared to Placebo) reduces plasma F2 isoprostane and increases potential antioxidant (PAO) levels.
3. To assess the tolerability of Cerefolin® NAC
4. To explore the effects of Cerefolin® NAC on a 6-month change in: (a)global and specific cognitive domains in a standardized neuropsychological test battery,(b) quality of life as measured by SF-36, (c)instrumental and basic activities of daily living, (d)MADRS; and (e)performance-based physical function.
5. To explore if a change in homocysteine level is related to a change in the plasma glutathione, hs-CRP, IL-6, TNF-α, F2-isoprostane, and PAO levels and to a change in the ratio of Aβ42 to Aβ40.
6. To explore the effects of MS AG2756, APOE and MFTHR on the relationship examined in Secondary Objective #5.
7. To explore the relationship of B12 status and status to cognition

NOTE: For individuals successfully completing the 6-month blinded phase, there is an 12-month open-label extension of Cerefolin NAC + multivitamin. The primary purpose of the exploratory, open-label extension phase of the CERE-001 study is to systematically collect long-term safety data on CEREFOLIN NAC usage over an additional 12-month period.

participantFlowModule.preAssignmentDetails: Consented participants underwent a screening evaluation to ensure inclusion criteria were met prior to study treatment assignment and one month run-in treatment with a multivitamin only. Of 124 consented individuals, 20 discontinued prior to randomization due to new medical conditions (9), declining participation (5), and for other reasons (6).
participantFlowModule.recruitmentDetails: Between March 2008 and September 2009, persons expressing study interest at community presentations or at the Rush Memory Clinic were contacted. Of 524 persons expressing interest, 400 were excluded before consenting for having excluding clinical diagnoses(227), participation refusal (119), and other exclusions medication (54).

measures.title: potential anti-oxidant (PAO)
measures.description: Potential anti-oxidant (PAO) measures the antioxidant capacity of a serum sample to reduce cupric ions from Cu++ to Cu+.

outcomeMeasures.title: Six Month Blood Levels of Homocysteine, Glutathione, and the Ratio of Aβ42 to Aβ40 (as a Percent of Baseline Levels) After Daily Intake of Cerefolin NAC Plus a Multivitamin Versus a Multivitamin Only
outcomeMeasures.description: Primary outcome markers were plasma homocysteine (tHcy), glutathione, and the ratio of amyloid proteins, Aβ42 and Aβ40. Plasma tHcy and glutathione were assayed using a high performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) with fluorescence detection method. Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assays (ELISA) were used for Aβ42 (Wako Chemicals USA, Inc., Richmond, VA) and Aβ40 (Invitrogen Corporation, Canarillo, CA) detection. Primary analyses utilized Last Observation Carried Forward (LOCF) to assess the primary biomarker level at 6 months versus baseline. Six month levels in biomarker outcomes were compared using t-tests of the logarithmically transformed values and the antilogarithm was applied to the SDs obtain 95% confidence intervals (95% CIs). A significant difference between treatments was needed for at least one of the primary outcome variables (tHcy, glutathione, or the Aβ42 to Aβ40 ratio) to declare the study positive.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: The Intent-to-Treat (ITT) cohort included randomized subjects taking at least one study treatment dose. Primary analyses utilized Last Observation Carried Forward (LOCF) to assess 6 month levels in the primary biomarkers. 2-sided, t-test p-value for group differences was only significant (\<0.05) for 6-month homocysteine level.

outcomeMeasures.description: Mean study product compliance was measured as the actual number of study product tablets taken as a percent of the maximum study product tablets that could have been taken during the intervention period.

outcomeMeasures.title: Six Month Levels of Inflammation and Oxidative Stress Markers(as a Percent of Baseline Levels) After Daily Treatment With Cerefolin NAC and a Multivitamin or a Multivitamin Only
outcomeMeasures.description: Outcome measures were 6-month levels of highly sensitive c-reactive protein (hs-CRP), tumor necrosis factor alpha (TNF-alpha), interleukin-6 (IL-6), malondialdehyde, and potential anti-oxidant (PAO)in blood samples as a percent of baseline value.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: All participants in Intent-to-Treat were included with last observation carried forward.

limitationsAndCaveats.description: No limitations or caveats to report.

drug: Cerefolin NAC (combination: L‑methylfolate ~5.6–6 mg, methylcobalamin (vitamin B12) ~2 mg, N‑acetyl‑L‑cysteine (NAC) 600 mg)
placebo: Standard multivitamin containing the Recommended Daily Intake for older persons (as described in trial)
explanation_target: Reason: The study tests Cerefolin NAC, a combination nutritional/medical‑food product made of small‑molecule nutrients (L‑methylfolate, methylcobalamin/B12, and N‑acetylcysteine) and aims to lower biomarkers linked to Alzheimer's pathology (homocysteine, oxidative stress markers, and beta‑amyloid). These are attempts to modify disease‑related biology rather than using a biologic (e.g., antibody) or only treating neuropsychiatric symptoms. citeturn0search0turn0search1turn0search12

Act: Extracted key details — intervention = Cerefolin NAC (ingredients and doses as above); comparator = standard multivitamin; primary outcomes = blood homocysteine, oxidative stress, and beta‑amyloid biomarkers (from the trial title). Cerefolin NAC is marketed/defined as a targeted nutrition/medical food for brain health and to lower homocysteine. Because the active components are small molecules/vitamins (not biologics) and the trial targets disease biomarkers, this best fits the 'disease‑targeted small molecule' category. citeturn0search4turn0search1

Reflect: Alternative interpretations — one could call Cerefolin a 'cognitive enhancer' because marketing and some outcomes relate to memory/cognitive function, but the trial explicitly measures disease‑related biomarkers (homocysteine, beta‑amyloid), indicating a disease‑targeting intent. It is not a biologic, nor is it focused on neuropsychiatric symptom relief, so 'disease‑targeted small molecule' is the most appropriate classification. Sources used to verify product composition and claims are cited above. citeturn0search0turn0search3
explanation_agent: Reason: The trial tests Cerefolin NAC, a fixed‑dose combination of small‑molecule nutrients (L‑methylfolate 6 mg, methylcobalamin/B12 2 mg, and N‑acetyl‑L‑cysteine 600 mg) and explicitly aims to change blood homocysteine, oxidative‑stress markers and beta‑amyloid biomarkers—i.e., it is attempting to act on multiple biological pathways (methylation/metabolism, oxidative stress, and amyloid‑related biology). citeturn0search0turn0search3

Act: Extracted intervention details and mechanistic intent from the trial description and product information: Cerefolin NAC composition and doses are listed by the manufacturer. L‑methylfolate and methylcobalamin are used to support methylation and lower homocysteine (a metabolic risk/biomarker linked to dementia), while NAC is an antioxidant and glutathione precursor intended to reduce oxidative stress; the trial also measures beta‑amyloid biomarkers. These facts map to multiple CADRO categories (J: Metabolism/Bioenergetics for homocysteine; G: Oxidative Stress for NAC; and A: Amyloid beta for the beta‑amyloid biomarkers), so the most appropriate single CADRO classification is R) Multi‑target. citeturn0search0turn1search2turn1search7

Reflect: Alternative single‑category choices (e.g., J: Metabolism for homocysteine lowering, G: Oxidative Stress for NAC, or A: Amyloid beta because amyloid biomarkers are measured) each capture part of the intervention’s goals, but none alone capture the trial’s stated multi‑pathway intent. Therefore per the CADRO instruction to consider 'R) Multi‑target' when multiple targets are indicated, I assign R) Multi‑target. If you prefer a single‑pathway label instead, J) Metabolism and Bioenergetics and G) Oxidative Stress would be the next most defensible choices. citeturn0search3turn1search2

Sources used (web search results referenced): manufacturer/product ingredient and product/targeted‑nutrition pages confirming composition and claims: Cerefolin product information and FAQ. citeturn0search0turn0search3; reviews/evidence on NAC as a glutathione precursor and antioxidant activity. citeturn1search2; meta‑analyses and cohort data linking elevated homocysteine and folate/B12 status to dementia/AD risk. citeturn1search7turn1search4
